revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit |unit_name=8th Field Ambulance |image= |caption= |dates=1916–19
1942–45
1966–72 |country={{flag|Australia|23px}} |allegiance= |branch=[[Australian Army]] |type=Medical |role= |size= |command_structure= |garrison= |garrison_label= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |colors_label= |march= |mascot= |equipment= |equipment_label= |battles=[[First World War]] * [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] [[Second World War]] * [[New Guinea campaign]] * [[Bougainville campaign]] [[Vietnam War]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |commander1= |commander1_label= |commander2= |commander2_label= |commander3= |commander3_label= |notable_commanders= |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label=[[Unit Colour Patch]] |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= }} The '''8th Field Ambulance''' was a medical unit of the [[Australian Army]]. It was original formed for service during World War I as part of the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]], and served mainly on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] between 1916 and 1918, before disbanding in early 1919. During World War II, the unit was re-raised as a [[Australian Army Reserve|Militia]] unit and served in Western Australia, New Guinea and Bougainville. During the Vietnam War, the unit served in [[Vung Tau]] in support of the [[1st Australian Task Force]] between 1967 and 1968, before being disbanded in 1972. The unit's designation is now perpetuated by one for the [[1st Close Health Battalion (Australia)|1st Close Health Battalion]]'s close health companies. ==History== The 8th Field Ambulance was first formed during World War I, being raised in Egypt in January 1916,{{cite web |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1014567/?image=2#display-image |title=AWM4 26/51/1: January – March 1916: 8th Australian Field Ambulance |work=War Diaries |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=15 January 2015}} when the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] was expanded following the unsuccessful [[Gallipoli Campaign]].{{Cite book|last=Grey |first=Jeffrey |authorlink=Jeffrey Grey |title=A Military History of Australia |edition=3rd |publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Melbourne, Victoria|year=2008|pp=99–100 |isbn=978-0-521-69791-0}} Assigned to the [[8th Brigade (Australia)|8th Brigade]], [[5th Division (Australia)|5th Division]], the 8th Field Ambulance was subsequently deployed to the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]]. Responsible for providing second line evacuation from [[regimental aid post]]s that were deployed forward with the attacking troops, to casualty clearing stations, Australian field ambulances at the time consisted of 10 officers and 224 other ranks and were organised into a headquarters and two company-sized sub-divisions known as the "tent sub-division" and the "bearer sub-division".{{cite book |last=Likeman |first=Robert |year=2003 |title=Men of the Ninth: A History of the Ninth Australian Field Ambulance 1916–1994 |publisher=Slouch Hat Publications |location=McCrae, New South Wales |isbn=9780957975224 |p=10 }} The unit's first major battle came during the disastrous [[Battle of Fromelles]] in July 1916, after which it served throughout the remainder of the war supporting the 8th Brigade's operations in France and Belgium.{{cite web |url=http://www.rslvirtualwarmemorial.org.au/explore/units/325 |title=8th Field Ambulance |work=RSL Virtual War Memorial |accessdate=15 January 2015}} The unit's last war diary entry was made in March 1919, after which it was disbanded.{{cite web |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/collection/AWM4/26/51/ |title=AWM4 Subclass 26/51: 8th Australian Field Ambulance |work=War Diaries |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=15 January 2015}} [[File:AWM E02843A 8th Australian Field Ambulance stretcher bearers.JPG|thumb|left|Stretcher bearers from the 8th Field Ambulance during the final Allied offensive of World War I, August 1918]] During the Second World War, the 8th Field Ambulance was re-raised as a [[Australian Army Reserve|Militia]] unit in [[Geraldton, Western Australia]], in 1942. It later deployed on active service during the [[New Guinea campaign|New Guinea]] and [[Bougainville Campaign]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.awm.gov.au/collection/070358/ |title=070358 |work=Collection |publisher=Australian War Memorial |accessdate=15 January 2015}}{{cite book |last=Walker |first=Allan |title=The Island Campaigns |series=Australia in the War of 1939–1945. Series 5 – Medical, Volume III |year=1957 |edition=1st |publisher=Australian War Memorial |location=Canberra, Australian Capital Territory |oclc=1293257 |pp=304–308 }} Another unit with a similar designation, the 2/8th Field Ambulance, was also raised within the [[Second Australian Imperial Force]]; this unit was formed mainly from South Australian volunteers and served with [[9th Division (Australia)|9th Division]] during the [[North African campaign]], including the [[siege of Tobruk]] in 1941,{{cite book |last=Howie-Williams |first=Ian |chapter=The Army Medical Services and the Campaigns in Tobruk and Syria, 1941 |url= https://books.google.com.au/books?id=9TSufplCU0YC&pg=PT220&dq=2/8th+Field+Ambulance+Tobruk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=aUW3VO77BYXi8AXBiYL4CQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=2%2F8th%20Field%20Ambulance%20Tobruk&f=false |title=A Medical Emergency: Major-General 'Ginger' Burston and the Army Medical Service in World War II |year=2012 |publisher=Big Sky Publishing |location=Newport, New South Wales |isbn= 978-1921941573}} before later serving during the [[Huon Peninsula campaign]],{{cite book |last=Dexter |first=David |year=1961 |title=The New Guinea Offensives |series=Australia in the War of 1939–1945, Series 1 – Army, Volume VI |edition=1st |publisher=Australian War Memorial |location=Canberra, Australian Capital Territory |oclc= 2028994 |pp=450, 471–472, 539, 764}} and the [[Borneo campaign (1945)|Borneo campaign]].{{cite book |last=Long |first=Gavin |year=1963 |title=The Final Campaigns |series=Australia in the War of 1939–1945, Series 1 – Army, Volume VII |edition=1st |publisher=Australian War Memorial |location=Canberra, Australian Capital Territory |oclc= 1297619 |p=497}} In early April 1966, the unit was re-raised with the intent to deploy to South Vietnam as part of [[Military history of Australia during the Vietnam War|Australia's contribution to the Vietnam War]], and was based initially at [[Puckapunyal, Victoria]].{{cite web | url= http://callsignvampire.org/content/view/33/37/ |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080908075319/http://callsignvampire.org/content/view/33/37/ |title=Callsign Vampire |archivedate=8 September 2008 |accessdate=15 January 2015}} The unit was staffed primarily by [[Citizens Military Force]] (CMF) medical officers on full-time service.{{cite book|last1=O'Keefe|first1=Brendan|last2=Smith|first2=Francis|title=Medicine at War: Medical Aspects of Australia's Involvement in Southeast Asian Conflicts 1950–1972|series=The Official History of Australia's Involvement in Southeast Asian Conflicts 1948–1975|volume=Volume Three|publisher=Allen and Unwin|location=St Leonards, New South Wales|year=1994|isbn=1863733019|p=111}} A year-long period of training followed before the unit finally deployed, arriving at [[Vung Tau]] in late April 1967, and taking over from the 2nd Field Ambulance. Forming part of the [[1st Australian Logistic Support Group]], the unit's main force of about 100 personnel established a field hospital at Vung Tau capable of supporting about 50 patients. A smaller team of around [[platoon]]-strength deployed forward inland, working directly with the [[1st Australian Task Force]]'s deployed infantry battalions. In 1968, the field hospital was redesignated the 1st Australian Field Hospital as the medical services in Vietnam were expanded,{{cite web |url= http://www.army.gov.au/Who-we-are/Divisions-and-Brigades/Forces-Command/17th-Combat-Service-Support-Brigade/1st-Close-Health-Battalion |title=1st Close Health Battalion |work=Who We Are |publisher=Australian Army |accessdate=15 January 2015}} although the forward medical detachment retained the 8th Field Ambulance designation. It was subsequently disbanded in 1972 following the conclusion of its tour.{{cite web |url=http://www.vvaa.org.au/oob.htm |title=Australian Order of Battle for Vietnam 1962–1972 |author=Ross, Brian |publisher=Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia |accessdate=15 January 2015}} The unit's designation is perpetuated by the 8th Close Health Company (8 CHC), which forms part of the [[1st Close Health Battalion (Australia)|1st Close Health Battalion]], which is assigned to the [[17th Combat Service Support Brigade (Australia)|17th Combat Service Support Brigade]] and was previously designated the 1st Health Support Battalion. 8 CHC was formed in 2011 from the 1st Combat Service Support Battalion's (1 CSSB) health company, following a restructure of Army health elements, which resulted in the CSSBs losing their integral health companies. 8 CHC is currently based in Darwin and provides close health support to the [[1st Brigade (Australia)|1st Brigade]]. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Colley-Priest |first=Langford Wellman |authorlink=Langford Wellman Colley-Priest |title=The 8th Australian Field Ambulance on Active Service |year=1919 |location=Sydney, New South Wales |publisher=D.S. Ford |oclc= 220154879}} * {{cite book |last=Tyquin |first=Michael |title=Little by Little: A Centenary History of the Royal Australian Army Medical Corps |publisher=Australian Military History Publications |location=Sydney, New South Wales |year=2003 |oclc=819680082}} [[Category:Company sized units of the Australian Army]] [[Category:Medical units and formations of Australia]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1916]] [[Category:Military units and formations disestablished in 1972]] [[Category:Military units and formations of Australia in World War I]] [[Category:Military units and formations of Australia in World War II]] [[Category:Military units and formations of Australia in the Vietnam War]]
